description: A rich, thick, and nutritious paste made from finely ground groundnuts (peanuts) and simsim (sesame seeds), traditionally served as a flavorful and energy-dense accompaniment to staple foods in Acholi culture.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Lakotokoto is a cornerstone of Acholi cuisine, valued for its high protein and fat content, which provides essential energy. It is a labor-intensive dish that showcases the traditional method of grinding ingredients by hand using a grinding stone (atoke). It is more than just food; it represents Acholi heritage, patience, and the importance of community, as the preparation is often a shared activity among women.

ingredients.name: Achi (Potash) - Optional
ingredients.notes: The size of a pea, dissolved in water. Used traditionally to tenderize and add flavor.

utensils.name: Modern Alternative: Blender or Food Processor
utensils.notes: Can be used instead of a grinding stone, though texture and flavor will differ.

steps.instruction: If using potash (achi), dissolve the small piece in 2 tablespoons of warm water and set aside. This will be strained and added later.
Dry roast the raw groundnuts in a pan over medium-low heat, stirring constantly, until they are lightly browned and fragrant. Be careful not to burn them. Remove and let cool.
In the same pan, dry roast the raw simsim seeds until they are golden and fragrant. Remove immediately and let cool.
Once cooled, rub the groundnuts between your hands to remove the skins. Winnow or blow to separate the skins from the nuts.

TRADITIONAL METHOD: Place the roasted, peeled groundnuts and roasted simsim on the grinding stone (atoke). Grind them together, adding a few drops of water occasionally, until they form a very smooth, thick, and oily paste. This requires significant time and effort.

MODERN METHOD: Place the roasted, peeled groundnuts and roasted simsim in a high-powered blender or food processor. Blend on high, scraping down the sides frequently, until a smooth, buttery paste forms. You may need to add a tiny amount of oil (1 tsp) to help it blend if the nuts are not releasing enough oil.
In a heavy pot, bring the 3 cups of water to a gentle boil. If using the optional grated onion, add it now.
Gradually add the groundnut-simsim paste to the boiling water, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon to prevent lumps from forming.
If using the potash water, strain it to remove any solid bits and add the liquid to the pot. Add salt.
Reduce the heat to very low. Let the Lakotokoto simmer gently for 15-20 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent sticking at the bottom. It will thicken significantly as it cooks.

cooking_indicators.visual: The paste will thicken to a porridge-like consistency, and oil may start to separate and glisten on the surface.

steps.instruction: Once it has reached a thick, rich consistency, remove from heat.
Serve the Lakotokoto hot as a relish.

serving_suggestions: Traditionally served with Atap (Millet Bread), Boiled Sweet Potatoes, Cassava, or Green Bananas (Matoke). It is a main accompaniment, not a light sauce.
